newsitem.title: USA: Head of N.H. Republicans pays $100,000 fraud fine.
newsitem.headline: Head of N.H. Republicans pays $100,000 fraud fine.

text.p: The head of New Hampshire's Republican Party has agreed to pay a $100,000 fine to settle federal charges alleging his development company was involved in fraudulent condominium sales in the late 1980s.
Stephen Duprey pleaded guilty on behalf of Northeast Community Development Group in February to nearly two dozen counts of filing false statements on bank loan documents.
While admitting his company's employees engaged in illegal practices, Duprey denied that he and other executives knew of the improper activity.
"Our company was negligent and I was sloppy ... and I accept responsibility for that inattentiveness," Duprey said after the sentencing Monday in U.S. District Court.

Federal prosecutors said the company engaged in "gifting" during 1988 to sell units at a Rochester condominium project. The illegal practice involves inflating sales prices and down payments from buyers to help them obtain larger loans and easier financing.

Prosecutor Peter Mullin recommended a $75,000 fine and told Judge Joseph DiClerico that the government decided to charge the company rather than individuals such as Duprey, because of "uncertain" evidence.
DiClerico accepted the guilty plea, but hiked the fine to $100,000. He also demanded that Duprey pay $4,400 to reimburse the government's costs incurred during the investigation.
After the hearing, Duprey blasted the government for pursuing the investigation after his company had been alerted to problems and corrected them. He called the investigation a "witch hunt."

"After having barely survived the real estate depression without going bankrupt, we simply have no more resources left to fight. I have expended over $175,000 defending myself and the employees of Northeast. The government, with limitless resources, could go on forever," Duprey said.
